TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit FormattedText extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides low-level control for drawing text in Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) applications.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText> object allows you to draw multi-line text, in which each character in the text can be individually formatted. The following example shows text that has several formats applied to it.
![Text displayed using FormattedText object](~/add/media/formattedtext01.jpg "Text displayed using FormattedText object") Example of a formatted text string
In terms of text features in [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)], <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText> is considered "low-level" because it processes text as graphical elements. Other aspects of text in [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] handle text in the context of controls that are dedicated to text (<xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBlock>, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox>), implement the flow document model (see [Flow Document Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/flow-document-overview.md)), or support the [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xps](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xps-md.md)] document model (see [Documents in WPF](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/documents-in-wpf.md)).
Many of the setter methods in <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText> have similarities to attached properties that are supported by <xref:System.Windows.Documents.TextElement>, but the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.TextElement> attached properties apply to the higher-level text support either for flow or [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xps](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xps-md.md)].
## Examples The following example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText> object and then applies several formatting styles to the text.
[!code-csharp[FormattedTextSnippets#FormattedTextSnippets1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/FormattedTextSnippets/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#formattedtextsnippets1)] [!code-vb[FormattedTextSnippets#FormattedTextSnippets1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/FormattedTextSnippets/visualbasic/window1.xaml.vb#formattedtextsnippets1)]

The Pixels Per Density Independent Pixel value, which is the equivalent of the scale factor. For example, if the DPI of a screen is 120 (or 1.25 because 120/96 = 1.25) , 1.25 pixel per density independent pixel is drawn. DIP is the unit of measurement used by WPF to be independent of device resolution and DPIs.

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Windows.Media.Geometry BuildGeometry (System.Windows.Point origin);
.method public hidebysig instance class System.Windows.Media.Geometry BuildGeometry(valuetype System.Windows.Point origin) cil managed
Public Function BuildGeometry (origin As Point) As Geometry

Docs.param: The top-left origin of the resulting geometry.
Docs.summary: Returns a object that represents the formatted text, including all glyphs and text decorations.
Docs.returns: The object representation of the formatted text.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When text is converted to a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> object, it is no longer a collection of characters - you cannot modify the characters in the text string. However, you can affect the appearance of the converted text by modifying its stroke and fill properties.
The following examples illustrate several ways of creating visual effects by modifying the stroke and fill of converted text.
![Text with different colors for fill and stroke](~/add/media/outlinedtext03.jpg "Text with different colors for fill and stroke") Example of setting stroke and fill to different colors
![Text with image brush applied to stroke](~/add/media/outlinedtext04.jpg "Text with image brush applied to stroke") Example of an image brush applied to the stroke
Text that is converted to and rendered as a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> object may not look the same as text rendered directly:
- Text converted to a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> object is not rendered using ClearType. In addition, the baseline of the converted is not snapped to a whole display pixel.
- Small fonts, such as those commonly used in body text, may lose legibility, appear blurred, and vary in appearance.
## Examples The following example shows how to create a <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText> object and to retrieve the geometries of the formatted text and its bounding box.
[!code-csharp[OutlineTextControlViewer#CreateText](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/OutlineTextControlViewer/CSharp/OutlineTextControl.cs#createtext)] [!code-vb[OutlineTextControlViewer#CreateText](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/OutlineTextControlViewer/visualbasic/outlinetextcontrol.vb#createtext)]

Docs.summary: Returns a object that represents the highlight bounding box of the formatted text.

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Windows.Media.Geometry BuildHighlightGeometry (System.Windows.Point origin);
.method public hidebysig instance class System.Windows.Media.Geometry BuildHighlightGeometry(valuetype System.Windows.Point origin) cil managed
Public Function BuildHighlightGeometry (origin As Point) As Geometry
public: System::Windows::Media::Geometry ^ BuildHighlightGeometry(System::Windows::Point origin);
member this.BuildHighlightGeometry : System.Windows.Point -> System.Windows.Media.Geometry

Docs.param: The origin of the highlight region.
Docs.summary: Returns a object that represents the highlight bounding box of the formatted text.
Docs.returns: The object that represents the highlight bounding box of the formatted text.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The bounding box region contains the entire formatted text area starting at the point specified by `origin`. The returned <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> object contains only the bounding box of the highlighted text and does not contain any rendered text.
The following example illustrates a way to creating visual effects by modifying the stroke and highlight of converted text.
![Text with image brush applied to stroke](~/add/media/outlinedtext05.jpg "Text with image brush applied to stroke") Example of an image brush applied to the stroke and highlight
## Examples The following example shows how to create a <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText> object and to retrieve the geometries of the formatted text and its bounding box.
[!code-csharp[OutlineTextControlViewer#CreateText](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/OutlineTextControlViewer/CSharp/OutlineTextControl.cs#createtext)] [!code-vb[OutlineTextControlViewer#CreateText](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/OutlineTextControlViewer/visualbasic/outlinetextcontrol.vb#createtext)]

Public Function BuildHighlightGeometry (origin As Point, startIndex As Integer, count As Integer) As Geometry
public: System::Windows::Media::Geometry ^ BuildHighlightGeometry(System::Windows::Point origin, int startIndex, int count);

Docs.param: The origin of the highlight region.
The index of the initial character the highlight bounds should be obtained for.
The number of characters the highlight bounds should contain.
Docs.summary: Returns a object that represents the highlight bounding box for a specified substring of the formatted text.
Docs.returns: The object that represents the highlight bounding box of the formatted text substring.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The returned <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> object contains only the bounding box of the highlighted text and does not contain any rendered text.

MemberSignature.Value: public double Extent { get; }
.property instance float64 Extent
Public ReadOnly Property Extent As Double
public: property double Extent { double get(); };
member this.Extent : double

Docs.summary: Gets the distance from the topmost drawn pixel of the first line to the bottommost drawn pixel of the last line.
Docs.value: The distance from the topmost drawn pixel of the first line to the bottommost drawn pixel of the last line, provided in [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_dipixel#plural](~/includes/tlasharptla-dipixelsharpplural-md.md)].

remarks.format: ## Remarks Extent incorporates any graphical elements that might be present in a glyph, including decorative elements that might go outside the line height, baseline, or overhangs. This value is dependent on characters appearing on the line and is thus not used (and should not be used) to derive line spacing. It can however be used to align the top or bottom of paragraphs with graphical elements, or for hit-testing.

MemberSignature.Value: public double[] GetMaxTextWidths ();
.method public hidebysig instance float64[] GetMaxTextWidths() cil managed
Public Function GetMaxTextWidths () As Double()
public: cli::array <double> ^ GetMaxTextWidths();
member this.GetMaxTextWidths : unit -> double[]

Docs.summary: Retrieves an array of text widths. Each element in the array represents the maximum text width of sequential lines of text.
Docs.returns: An array of maximum text widths, each width provided in [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_dipixel#plural](~/includes/tlasharptla-dipixelsharpplural-md.md)].

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the text lines exceed the number of elements in the array, the last element value is used for the remaining lines. If the array of lengths is not `null`, the array values of <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.GetMaxTextWidths%2A> are used instead of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.MaxTextWidth%2A> property value.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The default line height is automatically calculated, and is based on the font value that is passed as a parameter to the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.%23ctor%2A> constructor.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of lines to display. Text exceeding the will not be displayed.
Docs.value: The maximum number of lines to display.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.Trimming%2A> property to control how omitted text is represented when the text exceeds the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.MaxLineCount%2A>.

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the maximum height of a text column.
Docs.value: The maximum height of a text column, provided in [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_dipixel#plural](~/includes/tlasharptla-dipixelsharpplural-md.md)].

remarks.format:
## Remarks The last line of text displayed is the last whole line that will fit within the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.MaxTextHeight%2A> limit or the line number that does not exceed the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.MaxLineCount%2A> property, whichever occurs first.
## Examples The following example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText> object and then applies several formatting styles to the text, including <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.MaxTextHeight%2A>.
[!code-csharp[FormattedTextSnippets#FormattedTextSnippets1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/FormattedTextSnippets/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#formattedtextsnippets1)] [!code-vb[FormattedTextSnippets#FormattedTextSnippets1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/FormattedTextSnippets/visualbasic/window1.xaml.vb#formattedtextsnippets1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public double MaxTextWidth { get; set; }
.property instance float64 MaxTextWidth
Public Property MaxTextWidth As Double
public: property double MaxTextWidth { double get(); void set(double value); };
member this.MaxTextWidth : double with get, set

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the maximum text width (length) for a line of text.
Docs.value: The maximum text width for a line of text, provided in [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_dipixel#plural](~/includes/tlasharptla-dipixelsharpplural-md.md)].

remarks.format:
## Remarks Text will wrap to avoid exceeding the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.MaxTextWidth%2A> limit.
Glyph alignment edges must be kept within the line count limits. Because many fonts contain glyphs that slightly overhang their alignment edges, allow at least 1/6 em (font size) margin beyond the line count requested, to leave room for such overhangs.
A zero value for line count is treated as an infinite line count.
## Examples The following example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText> object and then applies several formatting styles to the text, including <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.MaxTextWidth%2A>.
[!code-csharp[FormattedTextSnippets#FormattedTextSnippets1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/FormattedTextSnippets/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#formattedtextsnippets1)] [!code-vb[FormattedTextSnippets#FormattedTextSnippets1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/FormattedTextSnippets/visualbasic/window1.xaml.vb#formattedtextsnippets1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public double MinWidth { get; }
.property instance float64 MinWidth
Public ReadOnly Property MinWidth As Double
public: property double MinWidth { double get(); };
member this.MinWidth : double

Docs.summary: Gets the smallest possible text width that can fully contain the specified text content.
Docs.value: The minimum text width of the text source, provided in [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_dipixel#plural](~/includes/tlasharptla-dipixelsharpplural-md.md)].

remarks.format:
## Remarks The following illustrated text uses the minimum text width for the source text, which displays as multiple lines. The minimum text width corresponds to the word that has the greatest width - in this case, the word "jumped". Notice that multiple words can appear on the same line, as long as their total width does not exceed the minimum text width.
![Text Formatter using the minimum paragraph width](~/add/media/textformatter03.png "Text Formatter using the minimum paragraph width") Minimum text width
If the value passed to <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.MaxTextWidth%2A> is greater than or equal to the value of <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.MinWidth%2A>, the text is formatted without ellipsis characters.
## Examples The following example shows how to use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.MinWidth%2A> property to generate the minimum text width for the formatted lines of text.
[!code-csharp[FormattedTextSnippets#FormattedTextSnippets3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/FormattedTextSnippets/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#formattedtextsnippets3)] [!code-vb[FormattedTextSnippets#FormattedTextSnippets3](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/FormattedTextSnippets/visualbasic/window1.xaml.vb#formattedtextsnippets3)]

Docs.summary: Gets the distance from the bottom of the last line of text to the bottommost drawn pixel.
Docs.value: The distance from the bottom of the last line to the bottommost inked pixel, provided in [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_dipixel#plural](~/includes/tlasharptla-dipixelsharpplural-md.md)].

remarks.format: ## Remarks The value is positive if the bottommost drawn pixel goes below the line bottom, and is negative if it is within (on or above) the line.

Docs.summary: Gets the maximum distance from the leading alignment point to the leading drawn pixel of a line.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When the leading alignment point comes before the leading drawn pixel, the value is negative.

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetCulture (System.Globalization.CultureInfo culture);
.method public hidebysig instance void SetCulture(class System.Globalization.CultureInfo culture) cil managed
Public Sub SetCulture (culture As CultureInfo)
public: void SetCulture(System::Globalization::CultureInfo ^ culture);
member this.SetCulture : System.Globalization.CultureInfo -> unit

Docs.param: The to use for text formatting.
Docs.summary: Sets the for the entire set of characters in the object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Globalization.CultureInfo> class holds culture-specific information, such as the associated language, sublanguage, country/region, calendar, and cultural conventions. This class also provides access to culture-specific instances of <xref:System.Globalization.DateTimeFormatInfo>, <xref:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo>, <xref:System.Globalization.CompareInfo>, and <xref:System.Globalization.TextInfo>. These objects contain the information required for culture-specific operations, such as casing, formatting dates and numbers, and comparing strings.
This method sets the culture information value for the entire text string. To set the culture information value for a subset of the text string, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.SetCulture%28System.Globalization.CultureInfo%2CSystem.Int32%2CSystem.Int32%29> method.

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetCulture (System.Globalization.CultureInfo culture, int startIndex, int count);

Public Sub SetCulture (culture As CultureInfo, startIndex As Integer, count As Integer)
public: void SetCulture(System::Globalization::CultureInfo ^ culture, int startIndex, int count);
member this.SetCulture : System.Globalization.CultureInfo * int * int -> unit

Docs.param: The to use for text formatting.
The start index of initial character to apply the change to.
The number of characters the change should be applied to.
Docs.summary: Sets the for a specified subset of characters in the object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Globalization.CultureInfo> class holds culture-specific information, such as the associated language, sublanguage, country/region, calendar, and cultural conventions. This class also provides access to culture-specific instances of <xref:System.Globalization.DateTimeFormatInfo>, <xref:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo>, <xref:System.Globalization.CompareInfo>, and <xref:System.Globalization.TextInfo>. These objects contain the information required for culture-specific operations, such as casing, formatting dates and numbers, and comparing strings.
To set the culture information value for the entire text string, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.SetCulture%28System.Globalization.CultureInfo%29> method.

Docs.summary: Sets the font stretch value for the object.

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetFontStretch (System.Windows.FontStretch stretch);
.method public hidebysig instance void SetFontStretch(valuetype System.Windows.FontStretch stretch) cil managed
Public Sub SetFontStretch (stretch As FontStretch)
public: void SetFontStretch(System::Windows::FontStretch stretch);
member this.SetFontStretch : System.Windows.FontStretch -> unit

Docs.param: The desired value to use for text formatting.
Docs.summary: Sets the font stretch value for the entire set of characters in the object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The font stretch value refers to the degree to which a font is stretched on the screen. <xref:System.Windows.FontStretch> supports type conversion behavior such that static values of the <xref:System.Windows.FontStretches> class can be used to initialize <xref:System.Windows.FontStretch> and fill parameters that are type <xref:System.Windows.FontStretch>. You can also call <xref:System.Windows.FontStretch.FromOpenTypeStretch%2A> to create a properly initialized <xref:System.Windows.FontStretch>.
This method sets the font stretch value for the entire text string. To set the font stretch value for a subset of the text string, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.SetFontStretch%28System.Windows.FontStretch%2CSystem.Int32%2CSystem.Int32%29> method.

Public Sub SetFontStretch (stretch As FontStretch, startIndex As Integer, count As Integer)
public: void SetFontStretch(System::Windows::FontStretch stretch, int startIndex, int count);
member this.SetFontStretch : System.Windows.FontStretch * int * int -> unit

Docs.param: The desired value to use for text formatting.
The start index of the initial character to apply the font stretch to.
The number of characters to apply the font stretch to.
Docs.summary: Sets the font stretch value for a specified subset of characters in the object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The font stretch value refers to the degree to which a font is stretched on the screen.
<xref:System.Windows.FontStretch> supports type conversion behavior such that static values of the <xref:System.Windows.FontStretches> class can be used to initialize <xref:System.Windows.FontStretch> and fill parameters that are type <xref:System.Windows.FontStretch>. You can also call <xref:System.Windows.FontStretch.FromOpenTypeStretch%2A> to create a properly initialized <xref:System.Windows.FontStretch>.
To set the font stretch value for the entire text string, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.SetFontStretch%28System.Windows.FontStretch%29> method.

Docs.param: The to use for text formatting.

remarks.format:
## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface> represents a combination of <xref:System.Windows.Media.FontFamily>, <xref:System.Windows.FontWeight>, <xref:System.Windows.FontStyle>, and <xref:System.Windows.FontStretch>. <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface> supports multiple constructors, one of which constructs based on a typeface name, another of which takes discrete values for <xref:System.Windows.Media.FontFamily>, <xref:System.Windows.FontWeight>, <xref:System.Windows.FontStyle>, and <xref:System.Windows.FontStretch>.
This method sets the font typeface for the entire text string. To set the font typeface for a subset of the text string, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.SetFontTypeface%28System.Windows.Media.Typeface%2CSystem.Int32%2CSystem.Int32%29> method.

Docs.param: An array of maximum text widths, each width provided in [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_dipixel#plural](~/includes/tlasharptla-dipixelsharpplural-md.md)].
Docs.summary: Sets an array of maximum text widths within the , on a per-line basis. Each element in the array represents the maximum text width of sequential lines of text.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the text lines exceed the number of elements in the array, the last value in the array is used for the remaining lines. Providing a valid array <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.SetMaxTextWidths%2A> will override any value provided for the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.MaxTextWidth%2A> property.

Docs.summary: Sets the for the object.

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetTextDecorations (System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection textDecorations);
.method public hidebysig instance void SetTextDecorations(class System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection textDecorations) cil managed
Public Sub SetTextDecorations (textDecorations As TextDecorationCollection)
public: void SetTextDecorations(System::Windows::TextDecorationCollection ^ textDecorations);
member this.SetTextDecorations : System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection -> unit

Docs.param: The to apply to the text.
Docs.summary: Sets the for the entire set of characters in the object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection> class specifies the types of text decorations to apply to the text. There are four types of text decorations: underline, baseline, strikethrough, and overline. These are described as <xref:System.Windows.TextDecorationLocation> values that are set on each item in the <xref:System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection>. It is common that the <xref:System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection> collection contains only one decoration, but the property uses the collection to provide for more advanced decoration effects by applying multiple decorations to the same text.
The following illustration shows the locations of the text decorations relative to the text.
![Diagram of text decoration locations](~/add/media/textdecoration01.gif "Diagram of text decoration locations") Example of text decoration types
This method sets the <xref:System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection> for the entire text string. To set the <xref:System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection> for a subset of the text string, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.SetTextDecorations%28System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection%2CSystem.Int32%2CSystem.Int32%29> method.

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetTextDecorations (System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection textDecorations, int startIndex, int count);
.method public hidebysig instance void SetTextDecorations(class System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection textDecorations, int32 startIndex, int32 count) cil managed
Public Sub SetTextDecorations (textDecorations As TextDecorationCollection, startIndex As Integer, count As Integer)
public: void SetTextDecorations(System::Windows::TextDecorationCollection ^ textDecorations, int startIndex, int count);
member this.SetTextDecorations : System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection * int * int -> unit

Docs.param: The to apply to the text.
The start index of the initial character to apply the text decorations to.
The number of characters to apply the text decorations to.
Docs.summary: Sets the for specified text within a object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection> class specifies the types of text decorations to apply to the text. There are four types of text decorations: underline, baseline, strikethrough, and overline. These are described as <xref:System.Windows.TextDecorationLocation> values that are set on each item in the <xref:System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection>. It is common that the <xref:System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection> collection contains only one decoration, but the property uses the collection to provide for more advanced decoration effects by applying multiple decorations to the same text.
The following illustration shows the locations of the text decorations relative to the text.
![Diagram of text decoration locations](~/add/media/textdecoration01.gif "Diagram of text decoration locations") Example of text decoration types
To set the <xref:System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection> for the entire text string, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FormattedText.SetTextDecorations%28System.Windows.TextDecorationCollection%29> method.
